owl:Ontology.dc:creator: Aitor Corchero (aitor.corchero@eurecat.org)
Pierre Bourreau (pbourreau@nobatek.com)
Yudith Cardinale (yudith.cardinale@gmail.com)
owl:Ontology.dc:description: This semantic model is focused on describing the occupants behaviour inside a building. For that, the proposed semantic model is based on the idetification of Drivers Needs and Actions for each occupant to make underestandable the occupant-building interaction and different comfort states.
owl:Ontology.dc:title: Hit2Gap Ontology-User Behavior
owl:Ontology.owl:versionInfo: This current version includes the initial version of the semantic model based on the diagrams generated.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Relation to define that an iser acto ober certain device changing their behaviour.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: acts

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Relation between the context and indoor or outddor factors.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: assigned to

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Relation between the context and certain sensor output
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: associated to

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The relation to represent the result of an action in terms of changing something inside the buildign (system, sensors, etc).
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: changes

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Relation focused on depicting the link between the users and the corresponding feedback
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: concerns

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: relation focused on indicating that certain user have defined certain behaviour
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has behaviour

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The relation to represent that a user has certain comfort requirements to be satisfied
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has comfort requirements

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: the relation to represent that an event have a set of contraints
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has constraints

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Indicate the relation between an event and certain context
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has context

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Property to define in the Drivers several functions to measure the comfort.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has Function

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: property to associate to the users their corresponding gender
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has gender
has indicator
property to indicate to the drivers the associations to certain indicators.

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: property to link the drivers with certain model results.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has model result

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: object property to represent the occupant attitude of the building occupants.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has occupant attitude

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: property to define the association between users and their daily activities
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has occuant characteristics

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: property to represent the probability of happen certain event
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has probability

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: property to associate the building occupants to certain role
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has role

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: property to asign to the building systems certain associated abstract state
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has state

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: property to represent the asignment to the driver of certain status
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has status

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: is assigned to
property to link user with modalitites
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: prefers

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: property to represent the action of receiving notification from the system according t certain building anomalies
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: receives

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: relation to represent the recepcion of alerts to certain users
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: receives alerts

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Haspart relation between a system and its parts.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: has subsystem

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: Relation linking an Observation (i.e., a description of the context, the Situation, in which the observatioin was made) and a Result, which contains a value representing the value associated with the observed Property.
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: observation result

owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:comment: The result time shall describe the time when the result became available, typically when the procedure associated with the observation was completed For some observations this is identical to the phenomenonTime. However, there are important cases where they differ.[O&M]
owl:ObjectProperty.rdfs:label: observation result time

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: Data property to define the age of certain building occupant
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: age

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: proeprty to define the date time of end of wrok
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: end of work time

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: Data proeprty to define the external ID regaring the time series stored in Mondas
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: external ID

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: text definition of the job type
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: job type

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: maximun value marked as an upper threshold measure
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: maximun value

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: minimun value marked as the lower limit of the threshold
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: minimun value

owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:comment: property to define the date time of start of wrok
owl:DatatypeProperty.rdfs:label: start of work time

owl:Class.rdfs:comment:
A unit of measure, or unit, is a particular quantity value that has been chosen as a scale for measuring other quantities the same kind (more generally of equivalent dimension). For example, the meter is a quantity of length that has been rigorously defined and standardized by the BIPM (International Board of Weights and Measures). Any measurement of the length can be expressed as a number multiplied by the unit meter.
More formally, the value of a physical quantity Q with respect to a unit (U) is expressed as the scalar multiple of a real number (n) and U: Q = nU
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Unit

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The ASHRAE Adaptive Comfort is a standard that provides minimum requirements for acceptable thermal indoor environments. It establishes the ranges of indoor environmental conditions that are acceptable to achieve thermal comfort for occupants. It was first published in 1966, and since 2004 has been updated periodically by a technical committee of industry experts in ASHRAE (American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers). The most recent version of the standard was published in 2013.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ASHRAE Adaptive Comfort

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Standard that includes prescriptive requirements for the following: - Building Envelope: minimum wall insulation, minimum roof insulation, roof reflectance, minimum glazing performance - HVAC: minimum equipment efficiency, minimum system features, limitation on reheat, limitation on fan power - Domestic Hot Water: minimum equipment efficiency, minimum system features - Power: transformer efficiency, automatic receptacle controls, energy monitoring - Lighting: maximum indoor lighting power density (LPD, expressed in Watts/Sq.Ft.), minimum lighting controls, exterior lighting, parking garage lighting - Other Equipment: electric motors, potable water booster pumps, elevators, and escalators
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ASHRAE Adaptive Envelope

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The acoustic comfort refers to the models to measure the level of background noise within an aceptable range.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Acoustic Comfort

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Actions are the specific building interactions performed by the building occupants. This actions can be caused by an initial discomfort or event as an occupant event. Nevertheless, the actions are connected with the drivers at time as the user changes a parameter in the building facilities. Moreover, the actions also has some influence over the needs due to this actions commonly are performed to satisfy user comfort requirements.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Actions

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Model that consist on modelling the occupant activity inside the building
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Activity Model

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Defined as the quick to notice any unusual and potentially dangerous or difficult circumstances concerning the building state.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Alert

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: As variables that serve to measure the habits and activities inside the building. Defined to register and contextualise the occupant events (building interactions with the different systems).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Behavioural Model

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines that the corresponding blind is close
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Blind Close

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines that the corresponding blind is open
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Blind Open

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to the state that a blind could achieve (Open or Closed)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Blind State

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: In reference to the complex states, this refers as the states that require for the combination of different facilities to determine an overall state. For example, one complex state is the determination of the energy state of the building that can be energy efficient state or energy inefficient state considering anomalous energy consumption (e.g., thermostat on at same time as the windows are open)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Building Complex State

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The building simple state refers to specific status of some building elements that highly impacts in the detection of building anomalies even related with energy or user comfort.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Building Simple State

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The building state allows to conextualise and determine the building facilities status. This building state determinaton has been divided into simple building states and complex building states.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Building State

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Comfort state is defined as the ocupant state according to the current building situation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Comfort State

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Event that limits the action of something.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Constraints

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Context in which applies the action
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Context

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines that the corresponding door is close
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Door Close

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines that the corresponding door is open
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Door Open

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines that the corresponding state of the Door (Open or Close)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Door State

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Drivers represent the environmental factors from the outside world that stimulate occupants in their inside world to fulfill a physical, physiological or psychological need
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Driver

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Is the quality of being frugal, sparing, thrifty, prudent or economical in the consumption of consumable resources such as food, time or money, and avoiding waste, lavishness or extravagance
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Energy Frugal

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Occupant trend to have no preference or being uninterested about building energy consumption and efficiency.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Energy Indiferent

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Occupant that is recklessly, extravagant or wasteful in the use of resources.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Energy Profligate

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Energy state is the combination of different direct measures or simple state measures to determine energy inefficiencies.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Energy State

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Environmental Building Factors refers to the building inddor and outdor fixeed conditions for comfort and discomfort.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Environmental Building Factors

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Class for measuring the building features and the environmental factors including indoor and outdoor parameters.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Equipement Model

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Circumstances that may be driving occupant actions such as waking up, sleeping, leaving for work or returning from lunch
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Event

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Defined to register the events that can be detected from the sensor readings.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Event Model

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: In building domain, Feedback is the actor retrofit with information regarding buildn state.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Feedback

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Is the model function to determine indoor and outdoor environmental building factors.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Function

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The Gender is is the range of characteristics pertaining to, and differentiating between, masculinity and femininity
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Gender

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The IAQ corresponds to the types of measurements to determine the inddor environmental health.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IAQ

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: This International Standard covering the evaluation of moderate thermal environments was developed in parallel with the revised ASHRAE) standard 55 and is one of a series of ISO documents specifying methods for the measurement and evaluation of the moderate and extreme thermal environments to which human beings are exposed (ISO 7243, ISO 7933 and ISO/TR 11079, all three dealing with extreme environmental conditions, are others in the series).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ISO Adaptive Comfort

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to the performance of any action in the building.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Inaction

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Complementing the Driver information, the indicator refers to the optimal measure that indicates the state or level of something.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Indicator

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Considering the environmental factors and the context definition, the indoor class refers to those events that occur inside the building.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Indoor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Refers to the notification mode to the users. This notification could be via SMS, e-mail or telephone
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Modality

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Model result is defined by the outputs of applying several user behaviour model according to the collected data.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Model Result

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Needs represent the physical and non-physical requirements of the occupant's inside world that must be met in order to ensure the satisfaction of the occupant with their environment
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Needs

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The Notification refers to the mechanims to provide highlighted information to the building users.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Notification

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The value of the result of an Observation. An Observation has a result which is the output of some sensor, the result is an information object that encodes some value for a Feature.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Observation Value

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Specific occupant attitude inside the building
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Occupant Attitude

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Occupant behaviour influences building systems by movement or actions and further determines the building environment and energy consumption. Both the building environment and energy consumption in turn affect occupant behaviour through psychological, physiological and economic factors together with several external factors like comfort and culture.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Occupant Behaviour

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The occupant characteristics refers to the daily or most common activities that building occupants performs inside the building (e.g start or end work)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Occupant Characteristics

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Occupamt comfort is the occupant satisfaction with the building situation (thermal, lighting, etc) considering their specific comfrt ranges and parameters.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Occupant Comfort

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Occupamt discomfort will occur when building do not satisfy user requirements (comparison between needs and drivers).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Occupant Discomfort

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The occupant preferences refers to the building occupants prefeerences regarding the comfort sempsation.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Occupant Preferences

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Other kind of standards that could appear or considered within the measurement and assessment of the thermal comfort.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Other Comfort Envelope

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Considering the environmental factors and the context definition, the outdoor class refers to those events that occur outside the building.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Outdoor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The privacy refers to need of privacy associated to the user information and the need to maintain outside views.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Privacy

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Likelihood measure to occur certain action
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Probability

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The recomendation refers to the suggestions or proposals to improve the building efficiency or comfort.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Recommendation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Type of occupant feedback based on the building actor feedback using specific documants.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Report

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Depending on the interactions and the building type, the occupants interact with the building according to their capacities to perform building actions, as for example, seeing the building thermostats (ssn:Device) or actuating over the temperature fan coils (ifc:Actuator). At this point, it is interesting to consider that the occupants only perform such interactions if building managers permit them according to the building policies.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Role

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: It represent the season
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Season

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: State of the driver
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Status

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: System Actions are the intereactions between the different occupants and the building using the different building systems to modify the building states towards more comfortable states.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: System Actions

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Thermal Comfort is defined by the models to determine suitable indoor temperature associated to the user comfort.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Thermal Comfort

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The time of day and the day of the week are fundamental to the presence and location of occupants in a building. Some personal habits are time-driven, for example opening windows when first arriving at work or closing windows before leaving the office, or turning on lights when first arriving and turning off lights before leaving.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Time Behaviour

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Type of actor that corresponds to the h2g platform user.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: User

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Visual comfort criteria measure the ability of an individual to carry out tasks comfortably in terms of their photo-sensory perception of their environment. They are dependent on many factors including: light intensity, direction of light source, reflection of surfaces, contrast of surfaces, the nature of the task being undertaken and the photo-sensory response of the eye. International recommendations exist that specify the minimum level of illuminance required to provide visual comfort for various tasks and locations. As with thermal comfort temperatures, these light levels were derived experimentally and reflect an average person engaged in a specific activity within a defined environment.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Visual Comfort

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines the state of the specific window (Open or Close)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Window State

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines that the corresponding Window is close
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Windows Close

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines that the corresponding windows is open
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Windows Open

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines the corrresponding building space have nobody inside (empty room)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Zone Empty

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines the number of people that are in a specific building space. In an abstract way, it determines wether the building space is empty or occupied.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Zone Occupancy

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Determines the corresponding building space have someone inside. Thus, the specific building space have one or more people inside.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Zone Occupied

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A device is a physical piece of technology - a system in a box. Devices may of course be built of smaller devices and software components (i.e. systems have components).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Device

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A feature is an abstraction of real world phenomena (thing, person, event, etc).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Feature of Interest

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An Observation is a Situation in which a Sensing method has been used to estimate or calculate a value of a Property of a FeatureOfInterest. Links to Sensing and Sensor describe what made the Observation and how; links to Property and Feature detail what was sensed; the result is the output of a Sensor; other metadata details times etc.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Observation

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An observable Quality of an Event or Object. That is, not a quality of an abstract entity as is also allowed by DUL's Quality, but rather an aspect of an entity that is intrinsic to and cannot exist without the entity and is observable by a sensor.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Property

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sensing device is a device that implements sensing.
http://purl.oclc.org/NET/ssnx/ssn#SensingDevice
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sensing Device

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sensor can do (implements) sensing: that is, a sensor is any entity that can follow a sensing method and thus observe some Property of a FeatureOfInterest. Sensors may be physical devices, computational methods, a laboratory setup with a person following a method, or any other thing that can follow a Sensing Method to observe a Property.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sensor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sensor outputs a piece of information (an observed value), the value itself being represented by an ObservationValue.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Sensor Output

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: System is a unit of abstraction for pieces of infrastructure (and we largely care that they are) for sensing. A system has components, its subsystems, which are other systems.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: System

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: The IfcActor defines all actors or human agents involved in a project during its full life cycle. It facilitates the use of person and organization definitions in the resource part of the IFC object model.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcActor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: An actuator is a mechanical device for moving or controlling a mechanism or system. An actuator takes energy, usually created by air, electricity, or liquid, and converts that into some kind of motion.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcActuator

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A building represents a structure that provides shelter for its occupants or contents and stands in one place. The building is also used to provide a basic element within the spatial structure hierarchy for the components of a building project (together with site, storey, and space).
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcBuilding

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcDistributionControlElement defines occurrence elements of a building automation control system that are used to impart control over elements of a distribution system.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcDistributionControlElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: IfcOccupant is a type of actor that defines the form of occupancy of a property.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcOccupant

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A sensor is a device that measures a physical quantity and converts it into a signal which can be read by an observer or by an instrument.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSensor

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A spatial structure element (IfcSpatialStructureElement) is the generalization of all spatial elements that might be used to define a spatial structure. That spatial structure is often used to provide a project structure to organize a building project.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: IfcSpatialStructureElement

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: It enables compact representation of an interval corresponding to a single element in a date-time description (i.e. a specified year, month, week, day, hour, minute, second)
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Date Time Interval

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: Correpondence to the seven days used in the Gregorian calendar, and using the English names :Sunday, :Monday, :Tuesday, :Wednesday, :Thursday, :Friday, :Saturday.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Day Of Week

owl:Class.rdfs:comment: A temporal entity with zero extent or duration
owl:Class.rdfs:label: Instant
